course.name: Mechanical Engineering for Modern Life
course.description: Mechanical Engineering covers the broadest range of engineering amongst all related disciplines. In addition to the production of modern products useful in daily life, it is also associated with power generation and distribution, as well as new materials development. These will be used to explain mechanical engineering principles and their usage in product design and manufacture. Contents include Engineering Materials, Solid Mechanics and Structural Design, Renewable Energy, Indoor Environmental Quality, Smart Green Building, Energy Design, Sensors and Instrumentation, Robots and Controls, together with MEMS and LED Fabrication. First year students are preferred.

reviews.author: 當科
reviews.title: Think VERY carefully before taking any course taught by Professor Ng,
reviews.comment_content:
It is long, but read carefully. Trust me.

Believe it or not, a lot of content from the lecture PowerPoint slides are copied directly from the internet, sources including Wikipedia and lecture notes from other universities. That is very unprofessional and disappointing.

If we put aside the fact that the content is plagiarized, the PowerPoint slides themselves are still no good. There are 40+ pages of PowerPoint slides per lesson. The contents are overwhelming and unnecessarily in-depth. One example is when we were learning about metals, we were taught that they can be classified into ferrous metals, non-ferrous metals and super alloys. Fair enough. Then each classifications have a couple of sub-classifications, such as ferrous metals can be divided into cast iron and steels. Then we even have to learn about the sub-classifications of the sub-classifications. (e.g. Steels can be divided into carbon steels, alloy steels, high-strength low-alloy steels, stainless steels etc.) I don’t see the need to learn all that in an introductory course.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Ng reads straight from the PowerPoint slides every lesson, so there is no need to attend any.
reviews.comment_grading:
I have not received my final grade at this point. So you can be assured that I'm not here criticizing the course because I got a bad grade. I still believe this is a poor course no matter if my final grade is an A+ or an F.

From what I heard, it’s not too difficult to get a good grade. You will get a good grade if you are good at memorizing. But it’s pathetic to see that education is reduced to the ability to memorize facts.
reviews.comment_workload:
No quizzes, tests, assignments, projects, homework. A very good course to take if you don’t care about learning and want a good grade with minimal effort. Only one mid-term exam and one final exam, all MC questions.

This brings up another problem. The exam questions are just as poor as the PowerPoint slides. You will see MC questions with more than one correct options / no correct options, but you’ll be told it's your own problem if you raise any question during the exam.

reviews.author: haanouta
reviews.title: Reading lecture notes yourself = attending class
reviews.comment_content:
If you take this course you'll have a general idea of what mechanical engineering is as the aim of this course is to give some insights of what you'll be learning in the future if you declare it as your major.

The course is divided into 4 modules.

Module 1: Aerodynamics (in my opinion the most interesting one)
L3 introduction to aerospace engineering
L4+5 introduction to aerodynamics
L6 propulsion
L7 gas turbines

Module 2: Solid Materials
L8 statics and dynamics
L9 solid mechanics
L10 engineering materials
L11 metals
L12 polymers

Module 3: Design and Manufacturing
L13 control
L14 robotics
L15 engineering design
L16 manufacturing
L17 mechanism of machinery
L18 mems

Module 4: Thermofluids (L19-23 pretty much overlaps with the thermodynamics chapters in PHYS 1112 and L23 is what you've learnt if you took chemistry or physics as an elective for DSE students)

L19 thermodynamics
L20 heat transfer
L21+22 fluid mechanics
L23 energy
L24 modern buildings

Although it seems like there is a wide coverage of content that could somewhat seem intimidating, you'll only need to understand each concept at a surface level as in just read the lecture notes and that's the level of knowledge they expect you to have, you don't need to do anything extra like research unless you're really interested in the subject.

If you're worried about the calculations it isn't too difficult and most of the steps are given in the examples. So if you understand the steps you'll be more than ready for the exams.

There isn't any attendance.
reviews.comment_teaching: Pretty boring. Just reading the lecture slides and on some occasions adding examples to supplement what she's teaching, so reading the lecture slides yourself is a much more efficient way to use your time. However, during the times I was in class the professor was always willing to answer any questions that came at the end of the class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Like I mentioned above, just reading the lecture notes is more than enough to do well in this course so the mean is fairly high (around the high 80s for assignments and exams). If you want to obtain high grades just try to familiarise yourself with everything mentioned in the lecture slides, especially the examples given for calculation questions.

This term our grades were determined by this weighting:
assignments (20%)
mid-terms (35%) covering lectures 3-12
finals (45%) covering lectures 13-24

the mid-terms and finals this semester were mostly MCs and 5 short answer questions involving basic calculations.

It's fairly easy to obtain satisfactory grades for your assignments as most of the answers are directly from the lecture notes. Also for the midterms and finals you could bring your own cheat sheet.
reviews.comment_workload:
In terms of assignments, the workload is very light. You're only given 1 assignment per module and you have a sufficient amount of time to complete it. Also most of the answers could be found on the lecture slides.

I would give this rating an A, but after the mid-terms the content covered in lectures was uncalled for. EVERY SINGLE LECTURE AFTER THE MIDTERMS PRACTICALLY DOUBLED IN LENGTH. So that was a lot of catching up to do.

However, if you want to learn deeply about mechanical engineering, this may not be the one course that u are looking for, as the knowledge it covers is quite basic and brief. reviews.comment_teaching:
The topics covered are divided into three groups, each taught by one professor.
For professor Tao, the ppt is quite neat and well organised, with lots of images that help students understand the topics.
For professor Qiu, some of the ppt feel wordier, but it may be due to the topics xd.
Generally, all the professors are nice and willing to answer questions.
However for some topics, especially when the ppt is also quite dull, it may be pretty easy to get asleep lol
The lectures do not take attendance and for that semester, the lectures are conducted in mixed mode, u can go to the classroom or choose to use zoom, which is quite convenient.
reviews.comment_grading:
4 assignments in total (allowed to finish the assignments within a period like a week before the deadline), each covering different topics, and most of the answers are straightforward and can be found in the lecture notes, while a few of the questions, you may need to search online and watch youtube videos to get the answers, as the notes only talk a bit about that.

One midterm and one final exam (both f2f), the questions of both are similar to assignments, which are quite straightforward and can be found in the lecture notes. And we are allowed to prepare a piece of cheat sheet, A4 and both sides, and bring it to the room or hall of the exam.

All in all, the course is quite easy as long as you have read the notes and know what is going on, the knowledge is not that difficult to understand
I get an A- in the end
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is quite light, with only 4 assignments which can be finished in a short time. For the midterm and final, only need to read through the notes and write the important or hard-to-remember knowledge down on the cheat sheet, then you should be able to make it.
And the lectures are quite relaxing, just listen to professors explaining and talking, and no discussions are required (but sometimes, only 1-2 times, the professors MIGHT just want to ask sb a question, but even if u don't know the answer, it's no big deal).

reviews.comment_content:
This course is probably highly recommended by SENG for first-year inductees who are deciding on a major.

The course covers four modules, each one containing 4-6 lectures' worth of information, with an accompanying assignment (3-5 pages, 65% MC, 35% FRQ) near its conclusion. Each module will introduce students to an important aspect of mechanical engineering and covers each subject with satisfying detail. Concepts are not difficult to grasp but may be overwhelming if one attempts to cram.

Though the course provides an introduction to mechanical engineering, there is nothing in the course that is essential to your progression in the said major. Nevertheless, it is an adequate eye-opener to the courses you will take should you declare the major.
reviews.comment_teaching: There are a total of 7 module instructors, 2 teaching assistants and 1 course coordinator (Prof. Hong Tao) responsible for the direction and delivery of the course's content and lectures. Each lecturer is highly knowledgeable about the content they deliver, but they generally do not offer anything outside of reading off the lecture notes.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading policy:

Assignments (4): 20%
Mid-term exam (1): 40%
Final exam (1): 40%

This is arguably favourable.
reviews.comment_workload:
As mentioned, lecturers generally read off the lecture slides without providing much additional input during class. Because these lecture notes are provided online and *are the only references provided that are relevant to the scope of the class*, it is feasible to study the lecture notes oneself in lieu of attending the lecture itself; indeed, many have found this a much wiser use of their time and as such the current present/enrolled ratio has dwindled to an embarrassing low.

Besides going over the study notes, you will have four assignments, each due after the last lecture in that module has been delivered. The answers to most of the questions in the assignments are directly found from the lecture notes, with very little calculations, so if one is familiar with the contents of the module, the assignments will be very simple indeed.

You will also face two examinations, the mid-term and the final. You are allowed a handwritten, one-sided A4 cheat sheet for the mid-term. The mid-term exam is fairly straightforward. You will recognise many questions from the assignments, so if you did your assignments with good knowledge of the information in the modules, the mid-term will be easy to handle.
